title: 105_hr4818
content: The Act is titled the "Asset-Building for Working Americans Act." The Congress acknowledges that existing resource limitations in public assistance programs may discourage working families from building long-term assets to escape poverty. Adjusting these limitations to disregard savings from earned income tax credits can help low-income families access temporary assistance while working towards financial stability. Adjusting limitations to disregard savings from earned income tax credits for 12 months can help working families build long-term security through assets while still receiving temporary public assistance. 33% of US households, and 60% of African-American households, have no financial assets. Additionally, 46.9% of children in the US live in households with no financial assets. SEC. 3 proposes a 12-month disregard of payments of Earned Income Tax Credit under the program of block grants to states for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families. The Social Security Act is amended to include a 12-month disregard of Earned Income Tax Credit payments for individuals receiving assistance under the State program funded by block grants. The Social Security Act is amended to penalize states that fail to disregard Earned Income Tax Credit payments for 12 months by reducing their grant by up to 2 percent for the following fiscal year, effective October 1, 1999. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to extend the disregard of Earned Income Tax Credit payments under the Supplemental Security Income program to a 12-month period starting from the month of receipt. This change applies to benefits from October 1, 1999, onwards. The Social Security Act is amended to disregard refunds and advance payments for 12 months in determining eligibility for medical assistance. Additionally, any refund of Federal income taxes due to the earned income tax credit is also considered in determining eligibility and amount of medical assistance. The Social Security Act is amended to exclude refunds and advance payments for 12 months from eligibility determinations for medical assistance. This includes refunds of Federal income taxes related to the earned income tax credit. The amendments apply to eligibility determinations made on or after October 1, 1999. SEC. 6. 12-MONTH DISREGARD OF PAYMENTS OF EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT UNDER PUBLIC HOUSING AND SECTION 8 RENTAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to disregard refunds of Federal income taxes related to the earned income tax credit and advance payments for 12 months in determining household income for eligibility purposes.
